TopicTitle: APOLLO (SATURN-V with F1 & J2, APOLLO CSM, LEM, LLRV). by OLDD (v.1.4. 09.05.14)

Articles.Content: Nice, though not quite realistic yet. Only a small cap in each of the fairings should come off. The rest stays intact. The retrorocket opening is located about halfway between the end of the fin and the fairing's tip. Here is a good drawing: http://up-ship.com/blog/?p=18085
Good to have you back, have made many the Moon (Munar) trips in you ships.

Good to have you back, have made many the Moon (Munar) trips in you ships.

Great! Please also add to the list Apollo CM RCS fixes.

1. Add 2 pairs of roll thrusters. Each pair about 45 degrees from either side of the side hatch. 2 thrusters firing to opposite sides on the same pod.

2. Move the top RCS pod to the other side. Both RCS pods for pitch are on the same side as the side hatch. This can be done by simply taking the top half of the CM (all that covered by the forward heat shield) and rotating it 180 degrees.

tell me more about APS functionality plz (ingame too). it r small boxes on aft side of S-IVB, right? may be a forgot it....

S-II retros present in model, but still unfunctional. i can add it as working separate part, it is simple, but rocket is too hard to assemble already. are adding additional separate parts be a right way?

Yes, radially attaching separation motors isn't that hard. In general, while people sometimes have trouble with complex stack setups, small parts with radial attachment are usually fine.

As for the APS, those are the small boxes on the side of S-IVB. They have three RCS thrusters and a small ullage motor (using hypergolic propellants):

They were used for ullage prior to TLI, and for controlling S-IVB during the coast phase. In-game, they'd make the S-IVB somewhat easier to maneuver.

well, i c ullage engine there. movies about S-IVB separation told us there were 3 torch, so - we should have 3 APS onboard, right? (but your pic shows only 2). or i have missed something? APS and separations engines must be separate devices (oh mein gott..)? its easy to add all engines and make it working (as standart RCS i guess), and assembly and staging the rocket will be interesting for me, but will such structure be interesting for other ppl? Some realism must be sacrificed for playability (i guess), for example my decoupleabled shrouds on S-IC. without it the effect of separation is poor.

Honestly if you simply model things correctly for realism, you can nerf it for playability all you want with configs, then it's simply a matter of making a config for realism, which Dragon, NK, or myself can do. They key is the model, with good transforms for RCS and engine thrust. With configs you can make things real or playable.

Edited September 20, 2014 by RedAV8R

There were indeed three separation motors and three APS pods. The three sep motors had a roughly four second burn, with the APS having a significantly longer and more controllable lifespan. FASA has the APS modeled well.

And just a note: the engine fairings on the S-IC were never ejected. The retrorockets fired, but the fairings themselves were never dislodged. Also, the launch escape system tower was jettisoned well after S-IC sep and skirt sep, once they had reached the fringe of the atmosphere. A ÃÂ¿Ã‘â‚¬ÃÂ¸ÃÂ´ÃÂ¸Ã‘â‚¬ÃÂ°Ã‘â€šÃ‘Å’Ã‘ÂÃ‘Â, I know. But just something to consider in your staging profile.

well, so i must do separate meshes for sep engines and APS, right?
Correct, the ullage solid rockets were different and not a part of the APS itself.

S-IVB had two ullage systems, yes. It had three separation/ullage motors, running on solid fuel. They were used to help with S-II/S-IVB separation and ullage the J2 for the orbital insertion. It also had two, much weaker APS modules, which ran on MMH and N2O4. They were used to ullage the J2 engine for TLI, and also contained RCS to control the stage's roll and also pitch and yaw when the engine was off. It was necessary, because the J2 needed to be restarted multiple times, but an ullage engine strong enough to perform the first separation/ullage burn would've increased mass of the whole stage.

Edited September 20, 2014 by Guest

Guys, tell me please, how to assemble the upper part of Apollo (CM+SM+LM).

The AJ1-137 engine hasn't any bottom attachment node, so it seems there is no way to attach anything below the service module ((

---

For those who have the same problem: first, connect the standard Apollo fairings, then attach the "Apollo CSM and LEM deployment device" to it with assembled LM (from subassemblies).

Edited September 22, 2014 by MaxP

right way to assembly LEM CSM pack.

1. start with LEM assembly, use something like probe as first detail.

2. save LEM as subassembly (without first detail).

3. press new and assembly CSM.

4. attatch SLA (it has 3 nodes, top, middle and bottom) to CSM by upper node.

5. open SLA.

6. attach LEM subassembly at second node.

Will you make an SLA with jettisonable panels? The version with hinged panels was used on Saturn IB flights, but was deemed too risky to use by the time of Saturn V. Because of that, Saturn V version of S-IVB used jettisonable panels.
